lines.speaker: u3872
lines.text: Yes, Colonel.

lines.speaker: u3871
lines.text: Hell, I could take you through it step by step, explain why your story stinks, but I won't insult your intelligence. Well all right, first of all: This is a wrestling picture; the audience wants to see action, drama, wrestling, and plenty of it. They don't wanna see a guy wrestling with his soul  well, all right, a little bit, for the critics  but you make it the carrot that wags the dog. Too much of it and they head for exits and I don't blame 'em. There's plenty of poetry right inside that ring, Fink. Look at "Hell Ten Feet Square".

lines.speaker: u3872
lines.text: "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas".

lines.speaker: u3871
lines.text: Look at "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas". These are big movies, Fink. About big men, in tights  both physically and mentally. But especially physically. We don't put Wallace Beery in some fruity movie about suffering  I thought we were together on that.

lines.speaker: u3876
lines.text: I want you in Dr. Gardner's office at nine o'clock.  You're out of control, Curran.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: Who are you guys gonna sell my file to this time?

lines.speaker: u3877
lines.text: Hey, that's Dr. Gardner, isn't it?

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: Bring 1976 up.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: Don't!  I know about your husband.  You still like girls, Beth?

lines.speaker: u3878
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u3879
lines.text: In the beginning.  Then I got to like what he did for me.

lines.speaker: u3882
lines.text: That's pretty cold, ain't it, lady?

lines.speaker: u3879
lines.text: I'm a writer,  I use people for what I write.  You write what you know.  Let the world beware.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: Was she ever a suspect?

lines.speaker: u3881
lines.text: Nope.  There was some talk; it never panned.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: What kind of talk?

lines.speaker: u3881
lines.text: The usual -- a girlfriend.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: He had a girlfriend?

lines.speaker: u3881
lines.text: Nope. She did.  Like I say.  It never panned.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: Thanks.

lines.speaker: u3881
lines.text: I hope I helped you out.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: You did.

lines.speaker: u3882
lines.text: What was the motive?

lines.speaker: u3886
lines.text: She said she didn't know herself, just sort of did it on impulse.  The razor just happened to be there.

lines.speaker: u3885
lines.text: We know you're not stupid, Ms. Tramell.

lines.speaker: u3883
lines.text: Maybe that's what you're counting on to get you off the hook.

lines.speaker: u3886
lines.text: He died -- about five or six years ago.

lines.speaker: u3884
lines.text: He was shot.

lines.speaker: u3887
lines.text: This is painted on a backdrop from the Kabuki theater in Japan. I painted it after Joseph Beuys died. A rebirth painting. I felt like he could've painted it, or maybe someone else was painting it instead of me. The Chinese calligraphers used to change their name mid-career so they could start over as someone else..

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: Do you ever get sick of it?

lines.speaker: u3887
lines.text: Of what?

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: The whole thing  painting.

lines.speaker: u3887
lines.text: No. It's one of the few times I feel good. I used to have to go to work and cook every day. That I got sick of.

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: What about the shit they write?

lines.speaker: u3887
lines.text: You're asking me this because of the 'lapdog' remark. I read that. The person that wrote that has the compassion of a housefly. That's your enemy, not your audience. Your audience hasn't even been born yet. It's a lie that art is popular. The only thing popular about it is that it's written about in newspapers. I'm surprised when anybody comes to my openings. There're about ten people on the planet who know anything about painting, and Andy's one of them.

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: I haven't felt like talking to him since that thing came out.

lines.speaker: u3887
lines.text: As long as I've known Andy, he's never asked me for anything except to speak to you about getting off drugs. He's painted my picture, we've eaten dinner in God knows how many places together. But he doesn't care about me. He cares about you. You're the only person he cares about. He's your friend. Fuck that article. You want a toasted bagel with cream cheese?

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: After the show we should take a nice long vacation. Maybe go to Hawaii. That's what I'm gonna do. I'm going to give up painting and start playing music again. I wanna sing.

lines.speaker: u3888
lines.text: That would be a pity because you're a real painter.

lines.speaker: u3889
lines.text: It's great that people are interested, but if anyone's going to buy anything, I'll handle it for you. Everything goes through the gallery, even if they come to your studio.

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: Sure.

lines.speaker: u3906
lines.text: MOTHAFUCKAH!

lines.speaker: u3890
lines.text: That's the same guy who did this painting.

lines.speaker: u3906
lines.text: I know that. Don't let him get away.

lines.speaker: u3900
lines.text: Jean? Hold this, please.  You'll get there. But it's good to have something to fall back on. That's why I became an electrician. It pays the rent. Y'know, I'm an artist, too.

lines.speaker: u3891
lines.text: I didn't know.

lines.speaker: u3900
lines.text: I sculpt. I'm really just starting to find myself. How old are you? Twenty? You're just like I used to be. I'm forty-one. And I'm glad I haven't gotten any recognition. It gave me time to develop.

lines.speaker: u3903
lines.text: OK! Goodbye!

lines.speaker: u3903
lines.text: I need this?

lines.speaker: u3899
lines.text: I need this?

lines.speaker: u3909
lines.text: Man, I was up on him years ago on the IRT.

lines.speaker: u3905
lines.text: You're selling and ending the culture. Not one bit of information. Only to get the money and growl with the power, man.

lines.speaker: u3909
lines.text: That's ignorant.

lines.speaker: u3910
lines.text: Well ... Come what may... Merry Christmas, Mr. Wayne.

lines.speaker: u3912
lines.text: Right.  Sure.  And "Peace on earth, good will toward men."

lines.text: I think you're jealous that I'm a genuine freak, and you have to wear a mask!

lines.text: Course you're feeling fine ... You almost made a monster the Mayor of Gotham City.

lines.text: I am the light of this city.  <u>And</u> I am its mean, twisted soul.  Does it really matter who's the "mayor"?

lines.speaker: u3912
lines.text: It does to me.

lines.speaker: u3916
lines.text: Yawn.

lines.text: Me, domesticated?  By you?  I doubt it!  You repulsive... awful... <u>penguin</u>.

lines.text: You buy this "blurry" business?

lines.speaker: u3916
lines.text: Women... nothing surprises me, Chip. Excepting your late mother... Who even knew Selina had a brain to damage?  Bottom line:  she tries to blackmail us, we drop her out a higher window.  Meanwhile I got badder fish to fry.  Yeah -- Oswald, please.

lines.speaker: u3915
lines.text: Well, um... funny thing, your penguins... they're not responding to the launch command.  Fact they're kind of turned around now... Like someone jammed our signal...

lines.text: Actually I have to split.  Take a "personal day."  You don't mind? Max, you're tops.

lines.text: Alfred, are you...?

lines.speaker: u3919
lines.text: Rather disappointed at how poorly I taught you proper housekeeping.  And quite well, it seems.  Thanks to you, son.  Thanks to you all.

lines.speaker: u3920
lines.text: Alfred has supported me my whole life.  Now I'm going to pay him back. I'm going to liberate him from his dismal life of servitude.

lines.speaker: u3924
lines.text: What are you talking about?

lines.speaker: u3920
lines.text: Servants, Masters, it's  ridiculous. Alfred is the sweetest, most noble man alive and he's subjugated all his life and dreams to someone else.

lines.speaker: u3924
lines.text: Alfred and Bruce are like family.

lines.speaker: u3920
lines.text: Paying someone to prepare your meals and do your laundry and clean your dishes, you call that family?

lines.speaker: u3924
lines.text: Alfred's happy here.

lines.speaker: u3920
lines.text: Happy.  You honestly don't know, do you? You can't even see what's in front of your own eyes.

lines.text: It'll take the satellites about a minute to re-align, but...damn!

lines.speaker: u3930
lines.text: Damn?  Damn is not good.

lines.text: Those targeting mirrors are frozen. The sun beam won't work.

lines.speaker: u3930
lines.text: Winded, old timer?

lines.speaker: u3922
lines.text: Don't make me kill you in front of the girl.

lines.text: One question.  When Batgirl and I rolled off the telescope, how come you didn't try and save us? It was the first time I fell and you weren't there to catch me.

lines.speaker: u3923
lines.text: I knew you could handle it.

lines.speaker: u3928
lines.text: Freezy, I'm feeling...hot.

lines.text: I find that unlikely.

lines.speaker: u3928
lines.text: Okay, my hair is brittle, my skin is dry and I don't care.  I'd weather blizzards to have you. You're the most perfect man I've ever known.

lines.speaker: u3925
lines.text: To be frozen.  To never change.  A life of perpetual ice-olation. There is little perfection in that.

lines.speaker: u3928
lines.text: What say we turn up the heat?

lines.speaker: u3928

lines.speaker: u3939

lines.speaker: u3933

lines.speaker: u3937
lines.text: Yo. Charlie. Gimmie an order of brain deep-fry. Extra well done. Hold the neurons.  Patient exhibits symptoms of psycho neural overload. Notation: obviously higher settings can be dangerous to the subject.  Riddle me this, Fred. What is everything to someone and nothing to everyone else? Your mind of course. And now mine pumps with the power of yours.  New from Brain-bok. Da pump. Think faster. Reason higher. Out-cog-nate every homey on the court of life. Da pump. Yeah.  Ho! Mark. I sense an odd penchant for the anagramatic. The acrostic. The crypto-graphic. What doth this bode? Answer me Marcutio, you little runt.  Fred, I must confess you were a wonderful appetizer. Simply divine. But now I yearn for a meal of substance. The main course. A wide and varied palette. Ah, to taste the mind of a hero. A nobleman. A poet.  A chick in a short skirt wouldn't be so bad either.

lines.text: ...Fired...your fired...your fired. You understand?! Fired!!

lines.text: How long's it been, Alfred? A quarter of a century?  It seems like yesterday. I guess we ended up doing more harm than good.

lines.text: Don't ever say that, sir. Don't ever believe it.

lines.text: If not for you I never would've made it. You know that. My own parents couldn't have...  ... The boy, Alfred. You'll both be provided for. Don't let all this got to waste.

lines.speaker: u3956

lines.speaker: u3958

lines.speaker: u3961
lines.text: Great.  Classic timing.  Why don't you ask her just to leave a date for the divorce?  I'll check my diary later.

lines.speaker: u3961
lines.text: It wasn't a dream, was it.  I have to go in to work and tell them Whistler's Mother now looks like Danny De Vito.

lines.speaker: u3959
lines.text: Well, Ahm....

lines.speaker: u3965

lines.speaker: u3960
lines.text: Thank you, sir.  Although, I'm afraid I don't quite see how we can ...

lines.speaker: u3965
lines.text: Good point Bernie - precisely the kind of perceptive interjection I'd expect from my new V.P. How can we, you ask, survive without Whistler's Mother - our single greatest asset?  Well, the truth is - we can't.  So what am I saying?  Will we find her again?  Never - this robber was clearly the work of a criminal of great genius.

lines.speaker: u3967
lines.text: ... in the distant future.

lines.speaker: u3961
lines.text: Bye, Bean.  Thanks for everything. And take care, huh?  I know it's insane, but I'm going to miss you.

Not only have you failed to protect your most valuable possession from theft - but you didn't even know it'd been stolen!  I'd sooner buy heroin from the guy who sells drugs outside my grandson's school than anything from you guys.

lines.text: Oh, honey... I didn't mean anything ... it's just too big for you two. I know these things.

lines.text: Your qu...?  But you're...

lines.text: Hellooo!  How's school?

lines.text: <u>Adam</u>!  <u>Adam</u>!

lines.text: ... And he told us that he had been living there since he was a child, working as a gardener. He showed us a room in the garage, where he said he stayed, and I... Well, I didn't really believe him, of course - but why the act?

lines.text: I have no idea...

lines.text: Another thing that baffles me, Doctor - what was his connection with the deceased? Major financial dealings, obviously - but our firm has no record of any such transactions.

lines.text: Hmmm. You say he showed you his garden?

lines.speaker: u4000
lines.text: Well, he said it was his, he walked us through it.

lines.text: I see.  Mr. Franklin, I must ask you and Miss Hayes to keep this incident with Mr. Gardiner to yourselves. There's no telling what he was involved in, and the matter may be extremely confidential. So please, not a word.

lines.text: Of course, Doctor, I understand.

lines.speaker: u3990
lines.text: Fine. Thank you, Mr. Franklin.

lines.text: Certainly, glad to be of help.

lines.text: I understand. I've never seen anything like this on television.

lines.text: Please, hold still, Mr. Gardiner.

lines.text: Wonderful, we'll all look forward to seeing you.  Is Eve around? I'd like to say hello.

lines.speaker: u3994
lines.text: Try again.

lines.text: I said - try again.

lines.text: I can certainly understand that...

The problem is: the NLF wants us to leave Algeria and we want to remain. Now, it seems to me that, despite varying shades of opinion, you all agree that we must remain. When the rebellion first began, there were not even shades of opinion. All the newspapers, even the left-wing ones wanted the rebellion suppressed. And we were sent here for this very reason. lines.speaker: u4415
lines.text: After I graduated college I was all set to go into my father business. Umbrella frames -- that's what he made. It was a sensible business, I suppose, but I didn't have the sense to be interested in anything sensible.

lines.speaker: u4421
lines.text: I suppose all this is leading somewhere?

lines.speaker: u4415
lines.text: It led me away from umbrella frames, for one thing. But that left me without any honest means of support.

lines.speaker: u4421
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: u4415
lines.text: When a man has no profession except the one he loathes, what's left? I began looking for people with more money than they'd ever need -- including some they'd barely miss.

lines.speaker: u4421
lines.text: You mean, you're a thief?

lines.speaker: u4415
lines.text: Well, it isn't exactly the term I'd have chosen, but I suppose it captures the spirit of the thing.

lines.text: I don't believe it.

lines.speaker: u4415

lines.text: Sorry, the name's Adam Canfield.

lines.text: No -- he's not the same. Alexander Dyle was interested in clearing up his brother's death. Adam Canfield is a crook. And with all the advantages you've got -- brains, charm, education, a handsome face --

lines.text: Your mouth's writing a check your ass can't cash, but if ya wanna buy some life, bring me the money.

lines.speaker: u4546
lines.text: I burned it.

lines.speaker: u4549
lines.text: What the fuck you mean you burned it?

lines.speaker: u4546
lines.text: Never could save a thing.

lines.speaker: u4549
lines.text: Now you get burned.

lines.speaker: u4547
lines.text: Right.

lines.speaker: u4548
lines.text: Then it's a deal.

lines.speaker: u4553
lines.text: Calm down...give the gun to me. You're out of control, son.

lines.speaker: u4550
lines.text: What the hell are you waiting for, goddammit!  Don't you see what he's doing!  He's hijacking the shipment!

lines.speaker: u4551
lines.text: You got what we need?

lines.speaker: u4553
lines.text: No, that son-of-a-bitch Walker is alive.

lines.speaker: u4551
lines.text: No names, this is an open line!

lines.speaker: u4553
lines.text: I don't give a shit, Qualen!  I had to be insane to ever tie up with a low-life, piece of shit like you.  They beat us.  A couple of fuckin' hick mountain boys beat the man no law agency ever could.

lines.speaker: u4551
lines.text: Get off the radio!

lines.speaker: u4554
lines.text: Mostly.  Armored cars can be hijacked.  Trains can be derailed.  But nobody can get to us in flight.

lines.speaker: u4553
lines.text: I haven't lost a bill in eighteen years, don't jinx me, Walt.

lines.speaker: u4554
lines.text: I think Treasury personnel are the most superstitious people in the federal government.

lines.speaker: u4553
lines.text: We should be.  Everybody wants what we have.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: If thou lose hope being weary in the days of distress, thy strength shall be diminished.

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: Fine, my boy, fine, fine.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: Father, I have tried, have I not?

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: You have, my son.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: I've done my best, have I not?

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: Indeed.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: And, Father, I've never been guilty of any institutional infractions, have I?

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: You certainly have not, 655321. You've been very helpful, and you've shown a genuine desire to reform.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: Father - may I ask you a question in private?

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: Certainly, my son, certainly. Is there something troubling you, my son? Don't be shy to speak up. Remember, I know all the urges that can trouble young men deprived of the society of women.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: No Father. It's nothing like that, Father. It's about this new thing they're all talking about. About this new treatment that you out of prison in no time at all and makes sure you never get back in again.

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: Where did you hear about this? Whose been talking about these things?

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: These things get around, Father. Two Warders talk as it might be, and somebody can't help overhearing what they say. Then somebody picks up a scrap of newspaper in the workshops and the newspaper tells all about it. How about putting me in for this new treatment, Father?

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: I take it you are referring to the Ludovico Technique?

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: I don't know what it's called, Father, all I know is that it gets you out quickly and makes sure that you never get in again.

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: That's not proven, 655321. In fact, it is only in the experimental stage at this moment.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: But it is being used, isn't it, Father?

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: It has not been used yet in this prison. The Governor has grave doubts about it and I have heard that there are very serious dangers involved.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: I don't care about the danger, Father. I just want to be good. I want for the rest of my life to be one act of goodness.

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: The question is weather or not this technique really makes a man good. Goodness comes from within. Goodness is chosen. When a man cannot chose, he ceases to be a man.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: I don't understand about the whys and wherefores, Father. I only know I want to be good.

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: Be patient, my son, and put your trust in the Lord.

lines.speaker: u4555
lines.text: Instruct thy son and he shall refresh thee and shall give delight to thy soul.

lines.speaker: u4572
lines.text: Amen. They cross themselves.

lines.speaker: u4557
lines.text: Mothballs, sir.

lines.speaker: u4558
lines.text: Now then. Face the wall. Bend over and touch your toes. Chief Guard inspects Alex's anus with a penlight.

lines.speaker: u4558
lines.text: Don't read it - sign it!

lines.speaker: u4567
lines.text: It says that you are willing to have the residue of your sentence commuted to the Ludovico treatment. Alex signs. Governor gathers up papers. Alex dots the last "i" and smiles.

lines.speaker: u4566
lines.text: Enough is remembered though, little Alex. Dim and Georgie laugh. They drag Alex to a low water through.

lines.speaker: u4560
lines.text: This is to make sure you stay cured. Georgie hits Alex in the stomach with his blackjack. Then, they push his head under the water and methodically start to beat him with their blackjacks. After a full minute of this, they drag him out, halt-drowned,

lines.speaker: u4565
lines.text: Hullo, son, how are you?

lines.speaker: u4571
lines.text: Are you feeling better?

lines.speaker: u4567
lines.text: Shall we go to my office?

lines.speaker: u4569
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: ...he's two floors below you.

lines.speaker: u4575
lines.text: In my office?

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: Where are you, what floor?

lines.speaker: u4575
lines.text: Seventh, files section.  What should I do?

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: He doesn't know you're up there!  Just stay right where you are!  Call the police!

lines.speaker: u4575
lines.text: Max, I'm scared.  Are you sure?

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: Yes!  Stay put, goddamn it!  Don't move from that spot...

lines.speaker: u4576
lines.text: You dizzy?  You want to sit down?

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: I'm...fine.  Fine.

lines.speaker: u4576
lines.text: You sure?  You look pretty shaky...

lines.speaker: u4577
lines.text: Lay it on me.

lines.speaker: u4587
lines.text: It's simple.  What was your pal Louis' first musical instrument?

lines.speaker: u4577
lines.text: I know the answer.  I know all there is to know about Louis.

lines.speaker: u4587
lines.text: Then let's have it.

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: As a token of my appreciation for your understanding in this matter, I'd like to offer you a discount for my services tonight.  Twenty five percent.

lines.speaker: u4578
lines.text: Twenty five?

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: Hell, make it fifty.  Same goes for any business we have in the future.

lines.speaker: u4578
lines.text: Very generous.

lines.speaker: u4584
lines.text: By the way.  Daniel said he was sorry.

lines.speaker: u4579
lines.text: What if they're wrong?

lines.speaker: u4585
lines.text: Not our call, Phil.

lines.speaker: u4579
lines.text: ...if they're wrong?!

lines.speaker: u4585
lines.text: This isn't our goddamn game!
